タイトル順/著者順/訳者順/ホーム

Botchan (Master Darling) / Kin-nosuke Natsume 著

坊っちゃん / 夏目漱石 著 / Yasotaro Morri 訳

Annotator: 高橋真弓

オリジナル:英語文&日本語文 / 対訳データ / このページにある対訳文について 7 of Botchan (Master Darling)

I pitied myself for coming from far off Tokyo to teach such a lot.
わざわざ東京から、こんな奴を教えに来たのかと思ったら情なくなった。
"Keep your mouth shut, and study hard," I snapped, and started the class.
余計な減らず口を利かないで勉強しろと云って、授業を始めてしまった。
In the next class again there was written: "When one eats tempura noodles it makes him drawl nonsense."
それから次の教場へ出たら天麩羅を食うと減らず口が利きたくなるものなりと書いてある。
There seemed no end to it.
どうも始末に終えない。
I was thoroughly aroused with anger, and declaring that I would not teach such sassies, went home straight.
あんまり腹が立ったから、そんな生意気な奴は教えないと云ってすたすた帰って来てやった。
The boys were glad of having an unexpected holiday, so I heard.
生徒は休みになって喜んだそうだ。
When things had come to this pass, the antique curious seemed far more preferable to the school.
こうなると学校より骨董の方がまだましだ。
My return home and sleep over night greatly rounded off my rugged temper over the tempura affair.
天麩羅蕎麦もうちへ帰って、一晩寝たらそんなに肝癪（かんしゃく）に障らなくなった。
I went to the school, and they were there also.
学校へ出てみると、生徒も出ている。
I could not tell what was what.
何だか訳が分らない。
The three days thereafter were pacific, and on the night of the fourth day, I went to a suburb called Sumida and ate "dango" (small balls made of glutinous rice, dressed with sugar-paste).
それから三日ばかりは無事であったが、四日目の晩に住田（すみた）と云う所へ行って団子（だんご）を食った。
Sumida is a town where there are restaurants, hot-springs bath houses and a park, and in addition, the "tenderloin."
この住田と云う所は温泉のある町で城下から汽車だと十分ばかり、歩いて三十分で行かれる、料理屋も温泉宿も、公園もある上に遊廓（ゆうかく）がある。
The dango shop where I went was near the entrance to the tenderloin, and as the dango served there was widely known for its nice taste, I dropped in on my way back from my bath.
おれのはいった団子屋は遊廓の入口にあって、大変うまいという評判だから、温泉に行った帰りがけにちょっと食ってみた。
As I did not meet any students this time, I thought nobody knew of it, but when I entered the first hour class next day, I found written on the black board; "Two dishes of dango--7 sen."
今度は生徒にも逢わなかったから、誰（だれ）も知るまいと思って、翌日学校へ行って、一時間目の教場へはいると団子二皿（さら）七銭と書いてある。
It is true that I ate two dishes and paid seven sen.
実際おれは二皿食って七銭払（はら）った。
Troublesome kids! I declare.
どうも厄介（やっかい）な奴等だ。
I expected with certainty that there would be something at the second hour, and there it was; "The dango in the tenderloin taste fine."
二時間目にもきっと何かあると思うと遊廓の団子旨い旨いと書いてある。
Stupid wretches!
あきれ返った奴等だ。
No sooner I thought, the dango incident closed than the red towel became the topic for widespread gossip.
団子がそれで済んだと思ったら今度は赤手拭（あかてぬぐい）と云うのが評判になった。
Inquiry as to the story revealed it to be something unusually absurd.
何の事だと思ったら、つまらない来歴だ。
Since, my arrival here, I had made it a part of my routine to take in the hot springs bath every day.
おれはここへ来てから、毎日住田の温泉へ行く事に極（き）めている。
While there was nothing in this town which compared favorably with Tokyo, the hot springs were worthy of praise.
ほかの所は何を見ても東京の足元にも及（およ）ばないが温泉だけは立派なものだ。
So long as I was in the town, I decided that I would have a dip every day, and went there walking, partly for physical exercise, before my supper.
せっかく来た者だから毎日はいってやろうという気で、晩飯前に運動かたがた出掛（でかけ）る。
And whenever I went there I used to carry a large-size European towel dangling from my hand.
ところが行くときは必ず西洋手拭の大きな奴をぶら下げて行く。
Added to somewhat reddish color the towel had acquired by its having been soaked in the hot-springs, the red color on its border, which was not fast enough, streaked about so that the towel now looked as if it were dyed red.
この手拭が湯に染（そま）った上へ、赤い縞（しま）が流れ出したのでちょっと見ると紅色（べにいろ）に見える。
This towel hung down from my hand on both ways whether afoot or riding in the train.
おれはこの手拭を行きも帰りも、汽車に乗ってもあるいても、常にぶら下げている。
For this reason, the students nicknamed me Red Towel.
それで生徒がおれの事を赤手拭赤手拭と云うんだそうだ。
Honest, it is exasperating to live in a little town.
どうも狭い土地に住んでるとうるさいものだ。
There is some more.
まだある。
The bath house I patronized was a newly built three-story house, and for the patrons of the first class the house provided a bath-robe, in addition to an attendant, and the cost was only eight sen.
温泉は三階の新築で上等は浴衣（ゆかた）をかして、流しをつけて八銭で済む。
On top of that, a maid would serve tea in a regular polite fashion.
その上に女が天目（てんもく）へ茶を載（の）せて出す。
I always paid the first class.
おれはいつでも上等へはいった。
Then those gossipy spotters started saying that for one who made only forty yen a month to take a first class bath every day was extravagant.
すると四十円の月給で毎日上等へはいるのは贅沢（ぜいたく）だと云い出した。
Why the devil should they care? It was none of their business.
余計なお世話だ。
There is still some more.
まだある。
The bath-tub,--or the tank in this case,--was built of granite, and measured about thirty square feet.
湯壺（ゆつぼ）は花崗石（みかげいし）を畳（たた）み上げて、十五畳敷（じょうじき）ぐらいの広さに仕切ってある。
Usually there were thirteen or fourteen people in the tank, but sometimes there was none.
大抵（たいてい）は十三四人漬（つか）ってるがたまには誰も居ない事がある。
As the water came up clear to the breast, I enjoyed, for athletic purposes, swimming in the tank.
深さは立って乳の辺まであるから、運動のために、湯の中を泳ぐのはなかなか愉快（ゆかい）だ。
I delighted in swimming in this 30-square feet tank, taking chances of the total absence of other people.
おれは人の居ないのを見済（みすま）しては十五畳の湯壺を泳ぎ巡（まわ）って喜んでいた。
Once, going downstairs from the third story with a light heart, and peeping through the entrance of the tank to see if I should be able to swim, I noticed a sign put up in which was boldly written: "No swimming allowed in the tank."
ところがある日三階から威勢（いせい）よく下りて今日も泳げるかなとざくろ口を覗（のぞ）いてみると、大きな札へ黒々と湯の中で泳ぐべからずとかいて貼（は）りつけてある。
As there may not have been many who swam in the tank, this notice was probably put up particularly for my sake.
湯の中で泳ぐものは、あまりあるまいから、この貼札（はりふだ）はおれのために特別に新調したのかも知れない。
After that I gave up swimming.
おれはそれから泳ぐのは断念した。
But although I gave up swimming, I was surprised, when I went to the school, to see on the board, as usual, written: "No swimming allowed in the tank."
泳ぐのは断念したが、学校へ出てみると、例の通り黒板に湯の中で泳ぐべからずと書いてあるには驚（おど）ろいた。
It seemed as if all the students united in tracking me everywhere.
何だか生徒全体がおれ一人を探偵（たんてい）しているように思われた。
They made me sick.
くさくさした。
I was not a fellow to stop doing whatever I had started upon no matter what students might say, but I became thoroughly disgusted when I meditated on why I had come to such a narrow, suffocating place.
生徒が何を云ったって、やろうと思った事をやめるようなおれではないが、何でこんな狭苦しい鼻の先がつかえるような所へ来たのかと思うと情なくなった。
And, then, when I returned home, the "antique curio siege" was still going on.
それでうちへ帰ると相変らず骨董責である。



CHAPTER IV
四
For us teachers there was a duty of night watch in the school, and we had to do it in turn.
学校には宿直があって、職員が代る代るこれをつとめる。
But Badger and Red Shirt were not in it.
但（ただ）し狸（たぬき）と赤シャツは例外である。
On asking why these two were exempt from this duty, I was told that they were accorded by the government treatment similar to officials of "Sonin" rank.
何でこの両人が当然の義務を免（まぬ）かれるのかと聞いてみたら、奏任待遇（そうにんたいぐう）だからと云う。
Oh, fudge!
面白くもない。
They were paid more, worked less, and were then excused from this night watch.
月給はたくさんとる、時間は少ない、それで宿直を逃（の）がれるなんて
It was not fair.
不公平があるものか。
They made regulations to suit their convenience and seemed to regard all this as a matter of course.
勝手な規則をこしらえて、それが当（あた）り前（まえ）だというような顔をしている。
How could they be so brazen faced as this!
よくまああんなにずうずうしく出来るものだ。
I was greatly dissatisfied relative to this question, but according to the opinion of Porcupine, protests by a single person, with what insistency they may be made, will not be heard.
これについては大分不平であるが、山嵐（やまあらし）の説によると、いくら一人（ひとり）で不平を並（なら）べたって通るものじゃないそうだ。
They ought to be heard whether they are made by one person or by two if they are just.
一人だって二人（ふたり）だって正しい事なら通りそうなものだ。
Porcupine remonstrated with me by quoting "Might is right" in English.
山嵐は might is right という英語を引いて説諭（せつゆ）を加えたが、
I did not catch his point, so I asked him again, and he told me that it meant the right of the stronger.
何だか要領を得ないから、聞き返してみたら強者の権利と云う意味だそうだ。
If it was the right of the stronger I had known it for long,
強者の権利ぐらいなら昔（むかし）から知っている。
and did not require Porcupine explain that to me at this time.
今さら山嵐から講釈をきかなくってもいい。
The right of the stronger was a question different from that of the night watch.
強者の権利と宿直とは別問題だ。
Who would agree that Badger and Red Shirt were the stronger?
狸や赤シャツが強者だなんて、誰（だれ）が承知するものか。
But argument or no argument, the turn of this night watch at last fell upon me.
議論は議論としてこの宿直がいよいよおれの番に廻（まわ）って来た。
Being quite fastidious, I never enjoyed sound sleep unless I slept comfortably in my own bedding.
一体疳性（かんしょう）だから夜具蒲団（やぐふとん）などは自分のものへ楽に寝ないと寝たような心持ちがしない。
From my childhood, I never stayed out overnight.
小供の時から、友達のうちへ泊（とま）った事はほとんどないくらいだ。
When I did not find sleeping under the roof of my friends inviting, night watch in the school, you may be sure, was still worse.
友達のうちでさえ厭（いや）なら学校の宿直はなおさら厭だ。
However repulsive, if this was a part of the forty yen a month,
厭だけれども、これが四十円のうちへ籠（こも）っているなら仕方がない。
there was no alternative. I had to do it.
我慢（がまん）して勤めてやろう。
To remain alone in the school after the faculty and students had gone home, was something particularly awkward.
教師も生徒も帰ってしまったあとで、一人ぽかんとしているのは随分（ずいぶん）間が抜（ぬ）けたものだ。
The room for the night watch was in the rear of the school building at the west end of the dormitory.
宿直部屋は教場の裏手にある寄宿舎の西はずれの一室だ。
I stepped inside to see how it was, and finding it squarely facing the setting sun, I thought I would melt.
ちょっとはいってみたが、西日をまともに受けて、苦しくって居たたまれない。
In spite of autumn having already set in, the hot spell still lingered, quite in keeping with the dilly-dally atmosphere of the country.
田舎（いなか）だけあって秋がきても、気長に暑いもんだ。
I ordered the same kind of meal as served for the students, and finished my supper.
生徒の賄（まかない）を取りよせて晩飯を済ましたが、
The meal was unspeakably poor.
まずいには恐（おそ）れ入（い）った。
It was a wonder they could subsist on such miserable stuff and keep on "roughing it" in that lively fashion.
よくあんなものを食って、あれだけに暴れられたもんだ。
Not only that, they were always hungry for supper, finishing it at 4.30 in the afternoon. They must be heroes in a sense.
それで晩飯を急いで四時半に片付けてしまうんだから豪傑（ごうけつ）に違（ちが）いない。
I had thus my supper, but the sun being still high, could not go to bed yet.
飯は食ったが、まだ日が暮（く）れないから寝（ね）る訳に行かない。
I felt like going to the hot-springs.
ちょっと温泉に行きたくなった。
I did not know the wrong or right of night watch going out, but it was oppressively trying to stand a life akin to heavy imprisonment.
宿直をして、外へ出るのはいい事だか、悪（わ）るい事だかしらないが、こうつくねんとして重禁錮（じゅうきんこ）同様な憂目（うきめ）に逢（あ）うのは我慢の出来るもんじゃない。
When I called at the school the first time and inquired about night watch, I was told by the janitor that he had just gone out and I thought it strange.
始めて学校へ来た時当直の人はと聞いたら、ちょっと用達（ようたし）に出たと小使（こづかい）が答えたのを妙（みょう）だと思ったが、
But now by taking the turn of night watch myself, I could fathom the situation;
自分に番が廻（まわ）ってみると思い当る。
it was right for any night watch to go out.
出る方が正しいのだ。
I told the janitor that I was going out for a minute.
おれは小使にちょっと出てくると云ったら、
He asked me "on business?" and I answered "No," but to take a bath at the hot springs, and went out straight.
何かご用ですかと聞くから、用じゃない、温泉へはいるんだと答えて、さっさと出掛（でか）けた。
It was too bad that I had left my red towel at home, but I would borrow one over there for to-day.
赤手拭（あかてぬぐい）は宿へ忘れて来たのが残念だが今日は先方で借りるとしよう。
I took plenty of time in dipping in the bath and as it became dark at last, I came to the Furumachi Station on a train.
それからかなりゆるりと、出たりはいったりして、ようやく日暮方（ひぐれがた）になったから、汽車へ乗って古町（こまち）の停車場（ていしゃば）まで来て下りた。
It was only about four blocks to the school;
学校まではこれから四丁だ。
I could cover it in no time. When I started walking schoolwards, Badger was seen coming from the opposite direction.
訳はないとあるき出すと、向うから狸が来た。
Badger, I presumed, was going to the hot springs by this train.
狸はこれからこの汽車で温泉へ行こうと云う計画なんだろう。
He came with brisk steps, and as we passed by, I nodded my courtesy.
すたすた急ぎ足にやってきたが、擦（す）れ違（ちが）った時おれの顔を見たから、ちょっと挨拶（あいさつ）をした。
Then Badger, with a studiously owlish countenance, asked: "Am I wrong to understand that you are night watch?"
すると狸はあなたは今日は宿直ではなかったですかねえと真面目（まじめ）くさって聞いた。
Chuck that "Am-I-wrong-to-understand"!
なかったですかねえもないもんだ。
Two hours ago, did he not say to me "You're on first night watch to-night. Now, take care of yourself?"
二時間前おれに向って今夜は始めての宿直ですね。 ご苦労さま。 と礼を云ったじゃないか。
What makes one use such a roundabout, twisted way of saying anything when he becomes a principal?
校長なんかになるといやに曲りくねった言葉を使うもんだ。
I was far from smiling.
おれは腹が立ったから、
"Yes, Sir,"
ええ宿直です。
